Enter our essay contest honoring Joe Cook.
Enter The Contest

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

When the Mayor of Kenner, Louisiana tried to ban Nike products because he didn't like that Colin Kaepernick had taken a knee to protest racial injustice, the ACLU of Louisiana fought back.

Just hours after receiving our letter demanding the ban be reversed, the mayor backed down and rescinded this unconstitutional policy.

Protesting injustice is a cherished American tradition, but Louisianans' First Amendment rights routinely come under threat — and students are often the first to see their rights infringed.

Student athletes who have taken a knee during the national anthem have faced retaliation and racial slurs. Students participating in walk-outs against gun violence have faced excessive and unconstitutional punishments.

That's why we want to hear from high school seniors about what the First Amendment means to them with a new essay contest in honor of our former executive director Joe Cook, a fierce and tireless advocate of civil liberties who passed away last year.

Joe Cook Memorial Essay Contest
What Does the First Amendment Mean to You?
Deadline: Friday, April 12
Prizes starting at $150!

Help us spread the word about this opportunity for high school seniors in Louisiana to write about what the First Amendment means to them.

The deadline for submissions is April 12 and prizes start at $150, so please share this message with educators and parents in your community.

Defending the First Amendment takes all of us — including the next generation of freedom fighters.

Thanks for sticking with us,

ACLU of Louisiana
